title: Walter Kimberley
text:
Walter Kimberley (28 September 1884 – 22 April 1917) was an English professional <a href="Association%20football">football</a> <a href="left%20back">left back</a> and <a href="right%20half">right half</a> who played in the <a href="The%20Football%20League">Football League</a> for <a href="Aston%20Villa%20F.C.">Aston Villa</a>.
Personal life.
As of 1901 and 1904, Kimberley worked as an <a href="engraver">engraver</a> and a packer respectively. While playing for <a href="Coventry%20City%20F.C.">Coventry City</a>, Kimberley worked at the <a href="Coventry%20Ordnance%20Works">Coventry Ordnance Works</a>. An <a href="Army%20Reserve%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">army reservist</a> since 1904, Kimberley rejoined the <a href="Coldstream%20Guards">Coldstream Guards</a> in August 1914, after Britain's entry into the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> and was appointed <a href="lance%20corporal">lance corporal</a>. The following month, he was captured by the <a href="German%20Army%20%28German%20Empire%29">Germans</a> at <a href="Maubeuge">Maubeuge</a> during the <a href="First%20Battle%20of%20the%20Marne">First Battle of the Marne</a> and spent two years as a <a href="prisoner%20of%20war">prisoner of war</a> in <a href="Prisoner-of-war%20camp">camps</a> at <a href="D%C3%B6beritz">Döberitz</a>, Dyrotz and <a href="Cottbus">Cottbus</a>. Beginning with a six-month stay in hospital with <a href="laryngitis">laryngitis</a> and <a href="bronchitis">bronchitis</a>, Kimberley's health declined during his internment and he was <a href="repatriated">repatriated</a> to <a href="Great%20Britain">Britain</a> in August 1916 with <a href="pulmonary%20tuberculosis">pulmonary tuberculosis</a>. He was immediately <a href="Discharge%20%28military%29">discharged</a> from the <a href="British%20Army">army</a> and fell into severe ill heath, permanently losing his voice and dying at home in <a href="Aston">Aston</a> on 22 April 1917. Kimberley was buried in <a href="Witton%20Cemetery">Witton Cemetery</a>, <a href="Birmingham">Birmingham</a>. He was married and had two children, one of whom died in infancy.
